head.title: Two Approaches: Teaching Online, and Off

hedline.hl1: Two Approaches: Teaching Online, and Off

abstract.p: Prof Ludwik Kowalski letter says August 6 discussion of on-line teaching did not touch on central issue of whether Internet teaching is any better than traditional instruction (S)

block.p: ''Online Teaching: The Battle in Cyberspace'' (Education Life section, Aug. 6) did not touch on the central issue: Is Internet teaching any better than traditional instruction?
What is needed is a comparison of outcomes; how well do students learn by these two methods?
''Online Teaching: The Battle in Cyberspace'' (Education Life section, Aug. 6) did not touch on the central issue: Is Internet teaching any better than traditional instruction?
What is needed is a comparison of outcomes; how well do students learn by these two methods?
Such questions must be answered discipline by discipline.

For the last two years, in my college-level courses, I have introduced the Internet as a component. Each class had an electronic bulletin board for questions and answers and for discussion of course-related issues.
This approach seemed to be productive.
But I still have reservations about eliminating direct human interaction, at least from science or mathematics courses.
As far as I know, the superiority of electronic education has not yet been demonstrated.
Online teaching is certainly better than nothing, but it is not ideal.
LUDWIK KOWALSKI Upper Montclair, N.J., Aug. 7, 2000
The writer is a professor in the department of mathematical sciences at Montclair State University.
